channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Widening Mideast Crisis: Political Divisions Over Conduct of War Roil Israel
item.description: Protesters demanded urgent action to free hostages, a war cabinet minister criticized the conduct of the war, and the Israeli prime minister publicly ruled out a two-state solution, rebuffing the United States.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv on Friday.

item.title: Fresh From Battles Won With U.A.E. Arms, Sudanese General Takes Victory Lap
item.description: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan was greeted by African leaders as if he had already won Sudan’s civil war. His forces have secretly been armed by the United Arab Emirates, an as-yet unpublished U.N. report found.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan of Sudan, left, poses for a handshake with President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa in Pretoria, in a photograph posted on General Hamdan’s account on the social media platform X.

item.title: In No Position to Fight a War, Pakistan Seeks an Off-Ramp With Iran
item.description: For two years, Pakistan has struggled with economic and political crises, an increase in militant attacks and souring relations with another neighbor, Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Iran’s flag over its consulate building in Karachi, Pakistan, on Thursday.

item.title: Japanese Talk Show Host Blazed Trails for Her Gender, and Now, for Her Longevity
item.description: Tetsuko Kuroyanagi has been one of Japan’s best-known entertainers for seven decades. At 90, she’s still going strong.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetsuko Kuroyanagi, 90, on the set of “Tetsuko’s Room,” in Tokyo, Japan, earlier this month. Her talk show has been on since 1976, earning a Guinness World Record last fall for most episodes hosted by the same presenter.

item.title: Israeli Women Fight on Front Line in Gaza, a First
item.description: After a long struggle for acceptance, Israel’s female combat soldiers are pushing new boundaries after rushing into battle on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Capt. Amit Busi, right, of the Israeli Defense Forces commands a mixed-gender unit operating in Gaza. The unit conducts search and rescue operations and provides security for a camp on the frontline.

item.title: French Police Officer Convicted in Théo Luhaka Abuse Case
item.description: Théo Luhaka, who was 22 at the time of the incident, sustained serious injuries when the police subdued him while conducting identity checks in a suburb northeast of Paris.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Théo Luhaka, who was beaten by the police, leaving the courthouse in Bobigny, near Paris, on Friday after hearing of the conviction of three police officers involved in the attack.

item.title: Ukraine Targets Russian Oil Plants, Aiming to Disrupt Military Operations
item.description: Kyiv hit an oil depot on Friday, the latest in recent attacks on such facilities as it seeks to inflict damage away from the largely deadlocked front line.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A screenshot from a video released by the Russian Emergencies Ministry on Friday appeared to show a fire at an oil storage facility in Bryansk, Russia.

item.title: German Lawmakers Agree to Ease Path to Citizenship
item.description: Proponents say the reforms will draw more skilled workers to the country, but that opponents warn the legislation will lessen the value of German nationality.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Tschentscher, the mayor of Hamburg, Germany, presenting a certificate at a citizenship ceremony at City Hall last year. Germany’s Parliament passed legislation on Friday that will make it easier for residents to apply for citizenship.

item.title: Prince Harry Withdraws Libel Claim Against Mail on Sunday Publisher
item.description: The prince had been suing Associated Newspapers over a 2022 article suggesting he misled the public over his security arrangements, claiming it was defamatory.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the Royal Courts of Justice, Britain’s High Court, in London in June.

item.title: Macron Shifts Rightward, and Charts a New Course
item.description: With a decisive turn toward youth and conservative ideas, the French president sets a path for his reshuffled government.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Tuesday during a news conference at the Elysee Palace.

item.title: Why Iran Is the Common Link in Conflicts From Gaza to Pakistan
item.description: Iran’s long history of building up proxy forces that fight its enemies around the region, as well as its conflicts with separatist and terrorist groups, have played into a spate of recent conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-government Iranians gathering near a banner that warns Iran’s enemies — in Farsi and in Hebrew — to “Prepare your coffins,” on Tuesday in Tehran.

item.title: Iran’s Missile Capability Is Forcing the West to Weigh a Response
item.description: Last year, the world discovered that Iran’s drones were becoming world-class threats and a favorite of the Russians. Now, its revived missile fleet is drawing attention, too.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: A building in Erbil, Iraq, was reduced to rubble by a missile strike launched by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps this week.

item.title: Protests in Russia Put Spotlight on Wartime Ethnic Grievances
item.description: The trial and conviction of an activist in the Ural Mountains region sparked one of the biggest outbreaks of social unrest since the start of the war.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: SOTA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen grab from footage shot on Wednesday showed police officers and protesters clashing in the Bashkortostan region of Russia.

item.title: In Guatemala, New Utopian Neighborhood? Or a Testament to Inequality?
item.description: The development of Cayalá is utopian, serene and prizewinning. As an elite stronghold in one of Latin America’s most unequal nations, it is also divisive.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Jody García and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A common space in Cayalá. Homes here are obtainable only by families from the country’s small, moneyed elite, or foreigners.

item.title: Quebec Man Pleads Guilty to What He Accused the Government Of: Starting Wildfires
item.description: A man who pleaded guilty to setting 14 fires in 2023 also shared misinformation and conspiracy theories about wildfires and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fire in northern Quebec last June. The majority of fires were started by lightning strikes.

item.title: U.S. Strikes More Houthi Targets in Yemen
item.description: The strikes, the sixth round in 10 days, targeted Houthi missiles that were poised to attack merchant and military vessels in the Red Sea, according to a White House official.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: John Kirby, the National Security Council spokesman, gave a briefing at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Annie Nightingale, Pathbreaking British D.J., Is Dead at 83
item.description: She was initially told there was no room for her on BBC Radio 1 because a woman’s voice lacked the authority of a man’s. Once she was on the air, she stayed there for 53 years.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Annie Nightingale in 1970, the year she became the first female disc jockey on BBC Radio 1.

item.title: A Message From the Premier League’s Rules-Free Future
item.description: Clubs of all sizes complain about cost-control rules and their implementation. But what would soccer look like if they went away?
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Families to Testify at Guantánamo Bay About Loved Ones Lost to Terror
item.description: Relatives of victims of the 2002 attack are expected to describe their loss to a U.S. military jury sentencing two Malaysian prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frank Heffernan and his wife, Bonnie Hall, at their home in Melbourne, Fla. “Not a day goes by that I don’t think of her,” Mr. Heffernan said of his daughter Megan, who was killed in the 2002 terrorist attack on the Indonesian island of Bali.

item.title: Britain’s Largest Steel Mill to Become Greener, at a Cost of Jobs
item.description: Tata Steel said it would replace blast furnaces with an electric furnace, a move that will cut emissions but also as many as 2,800 jobs.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unions representing workers at the Tata Steel plant in Port Talbot, Wales, said they were angry that their proposals to save jobs had been rejected.

item.title: London’s Highgate Cemetery Is Nearly Full. Can It Reuse Old Graves?
item.description: To lie in the vicinity of Karl Marx is competitive, with graves running upward of $31,000. Highgate Cemetery in London is trying to add more space.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Highgate Cemetery in London is the final resting place of Karl Marx, George Michael, George Eliot and 170,000 other Londoners.

item.title: Thailand Doles Out Longest-Ever Sentence for Criticizing Royalty
item.description: An activist received 50 years in prison for sharing TV and film content on social media that violated the country’s law against defaming its monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Thai Lawyers for Human Rights, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The political activist Mongkhon Thirakhot flashes the pro-democracy gesture of a three-finger salute ahead of going to a court in Thailand’s northern province of Chiang Rai, Thailand, on Thursday.

item.title: What Might Happen Next in the Genocide Case Against Israel
item.description: Exploring the role of the International Court of Justice in human rights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Joan Donoghue, the president of the International Court of Justice, second from left, and other judges arriving for the hearing of the genocide case against Israel brought by South Africa, at the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

item.title: Israeli Soccer Player in Turkey Removed Over Gaza War Post
item.description: The player, Eden Karzev, was fined and moved to an Israeli team. He is the second Israeli pro this week to run afoul of a Turkish team for displaying pro-Israel messages.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:description: Basaksehir players applauding fans after a match in March.

item.title: With Harsh Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Law, Uganda Risks a Health Crisis
item.description: The country had made great progress against H.I.V. Now terrified patients have fled clinics, and experts fear a resurgence.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Esther Ruth Mbabazi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Nur Shams camp for Palestinian refugees, in the West Bank.

item.title: At Davos, War Is on the Agenda, but the Focus Is on A.I. and Elections
item.description: The leaders and executives gathering at the World Economic Forum are obsessed with elections and artificial intelligence, not Ukraine or Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: A session on artificial intelligence during the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes in Iran
item.description: Also, corruption accusations in Singapore.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: People gather near rubble in the aftermath of Pakistan’s military strike on an Iranian village near Saravan, Sistan on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes in Iran
item.description: Also, corruption accusations in Singapore and travel predictions
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People gather near rubble in the aftermath of Pakistan’s military strike on an Iranian village near Saravan, Sistan on Thursday.

item.title: Netanyahu Rebuffs U.S. Calls to Start Working Toward Palestinian Statehood
item.description: The Biden administration and the Israeli government diverge sharply over how Gaza should be governed when the war ends.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli tank along the border with Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: Iceland Scrambles to Shelter Residents Made Homeless by Volcanic Eruption
item.description: In a country of fewer than 400,000, finding places for 3,700 residents is complicated by a tough housing market.
item.dc:creator: Egill Bjarnason and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Lava from a volcanic eruption destroyed some homes in Grindavik, Iceland. Others were spared.

item.title: Houthis’ Leader Says a Clash With the U.S. Will Strengthen Militia Group
item.description: Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said in a televised speech that the Houthis had always emerged stronger from confrontations with their enemies.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The Houthi militia leader, Abdul-Malik al-Houthi, seen during a televised speech in Sana, Yemen, on Thursday.

item.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger Detained Over Pricey Watch at Munich Airport
item.description: He’ll be back … to face criminal tax charges.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Arnold Schwarzenegger will face formal criminal tax charges, according to a spokesman for the Munich airport’s customs division.

item.title: In a Rare Move, Singapore Charges Official With Corruption
item.description: Accused of accepting tickets to “Hamilton,” air travel and soccer games in Britain, the transport official resigned before he pleaded not guilty in court.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Mark Cheong/The Straits Times, via Reuters
item.media:description: S. Iswaran, center, Singapore’s former transport minister, arriving at a court with his legal team in Singapore on Thursday.

item.title: Where Are People Going This Year?
item.description: Popular spots from years past are still favorites, but 2023’s crowds and heat waves are sparking interest in alternative destinations.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu

item.title: Will My Next Trip Be by Train Instead of Plane?
item.description: In Europe, Asia and the U.S., new and expanded train service is making rail a viable alternative to flying.
item.dc:creator: Paige McClanahan

item.title: How Violent Riots Engulfed Papua New Guinea’s Capital
item.description: A wage dispute prompted violent unrest in the Pacific nation, which experts call evidence of the effects of its demographic challenges.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Cottrell and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A damaged building after deadly riots in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, last week.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Missile strikes by Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Prepare your coffins,” a banner showing flying missiles hung in Tehran warned Iran’s adversaries.

item.title: Germany’s Economy Stalls Amid Falling Output and Political Bickering
item.description: The economy shrank last year and is not predicted to grow much in 2024. Farmers are angry, industrial output is falling and the government is bickering.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: A shopping district in Berlin. Germany’s economy contracted 0.3 percent last year, the worst performance among the 20 countries using the euro.

item.title: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes Inside Iran as Tensions Boil
item.description: The exchange of attacks came as the upheaval sweeping the Middle East threatened to expand.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: U.S. Moves to Bar Alejandro Giammattei, Ex-Guatemalan Leader
item.description: The decision against Alejandro Giammattei, who is accused of accepting bribes, signaled U.S. support for a new anticorruption drive in Guatemala.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alejandro Giammattei on Election Day in June in Guatemala City. He denied taking bribes related to a Russian project.

item.title: Palestinians Flee Gaza Hospital Refuge as Fighting Intensifies
item.description: Israel and Hamas are battling near a hospital in Khan Younis, near where the military said it had detected mortar fire. About 7,000 people had sought shelter on the hospital grounds, the U.N. said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: An Israeli strike on Khan Younis on Wednesday, as seen from Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Sunak’s Rwanda Immigration Plan Passes Vote in U.K. Parliament
item.description: The British prime minister’s plan to send refugees to Rwanda passed a critical vote, but more hurdles lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain ahead of the vote on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Iran Raises Military Threats
item.description: Also, how language affects memory as we age.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: France Rejects Genocide Accusations Against Israel in Gaza
item.description: “To accuse the Jewish state of genocide is to cross a moral threshold,” France’s foreign minister said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: France’s newly appointed foreign minister, Stéphane Séjourné, in Paris this month.

item.title: Softer Penalty for Somali Leader’s Son After Fatal Crash Prompts Outrage in Turkey
item.description: After a crash that killed a motorcycle courier, a son of Somalia’s president faced prison. Now it will be a fine of about $900.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:description: Mesut Ceki, a ⁠courier rights advocate, outside an Istanbul court on Tuesday. “Everything went differently in this case, as the person behind the wheel was in a position of power,” he said.

item.title: Nadya Tolokonnikova of Pussy Riot Marries John Caldwell
item.description: Nadya Tolokonnikova, a founding member of Pussy Riot, and John Caldwell have always prioritized being “helpful,” he said, over being happy.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Johnson Casts Doubt on Border Deal to Unlock Ukraine Aid, Defying Biden
item.description: A White House meeting between the president and congressional leaders did little to break the stalemate over aid to Ukraine, as the Republican speaker insisted on a tougher immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We must insist that the border be the top priority, ” Speaker Mike Johnson told reporters after emerging from a meeting with Mr. Biden and other congressional leaders at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: In Norway, a Proposed Ban on Foreign Adoptions Rattles All Sides of a Heated Debate
item.description: A policy body recommended this week that the country halt all foreign adoptions amid allegations of stolen children, falsified paperwork and for-profit adoption schemes.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: The Norwegian Parliament in Oslo. The announcement is the latest development in a sweeping adoptions scheme that first came to light in 2021 in Norway.

item.title: King Charles to Have ‘Corrective Procedure’ for Enlarged Prostate Next Week
item.description: The announcement from Buckingham Palace came shortly after the news that Catherine, Princess of Wales, had abdominal surgery on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Britain’s King Charles III and Queen Camilla at the Christmas Day service in Sandringham, England.

item.title: Gaza’s Phone and Internet Service Is Down for a Seventh Day
item.description: It is the longest blackout since the start of the war, according to the strip’s main communications company, which says it is unable to make repairs amid the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Palestinians walking through debris from damaged building in Rafah, Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Kenyan Cult Leader Will Face 191 Charges of Child Murder
item.description: The authorities say Paul Nthenge Mackenzie told his followers to starve themselves and their children to death in the Shakahola Forest, where hundreds of bodies have been exhumed.
item.dc:creator: Mohamed Ahmed and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Paul Nthenge Mackenzie, in a blue-and-white striped top, hugged his lawyer in a court in Malindi, Kenya, on Wednesday. A judge has ordered Mr. Mackenzie to undergo a mental health evaluation.

item.title: Greenland’s Ice Sheet May Be Losing 20% More Ice Than Previously Measured
item.description: The island is shedding 20 percent more than previously estimated, a study found, potentially threatening ocean currents that help to regulate global temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Icebergs calved from the Sermeq Kujalleq glacier in the Ilulissat Icefjord in Greenland in 2021.

item.title: A.I.’s Latest Challenge: the Math Olympics
item.description: Watch out, nerdy high schoolers, AlphaGeometry is coming for your mathematical lunch.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Kate, Princess of Wales, Is in the Hospital After Abdominal Surgery
item.description: Kensington Palace said Catherine, the wife of Prince William, would not return to public duties until after Easter. Separately, King Charles will receive prostate treatment next week.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Catherine, Princess of Wales, and Prince William, her husband, attending a Christmas Day service in Sandringham, England.

item.title: Iran Says It Won’t Hold Back on Using Military Power After Strikes
item.description: The country has hit targets in Syria, Iraq and Pakistan with missiles this week, signaling to hard-line supporters that it is not passive in the face of threats.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Prepare your coffins,” a hastily hung banner in Tehran warned Iran’s adversaries.

item.title: Explosion at Thailand Fireworks Factory Kills at Least 20
item.description: The blast leveled the facility and was the second such deadly accident in the country since 2022. The police are investigating the cause.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Suphan Buri Highway Rescue Association
item.media:description: The factory site, in Thailand’s Suphan Buri Province, after the blast. One resident told a local broadcaster that it could be heard a kilometer away.

item.title: After Iran Strikes, Pakistan Weighs Options for Response
item.description: Retaliation could risk drawing the country, which is already mired in political and economic crises, into Middle East upheaval that it has so far avoided.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Pakistani security officials inspect the scene of a blast in Quetta, the provincial capital of Balochistan province, Pakistan, today.
